revision.text:
{{Infobox religious building | building_name =El Tepozteco | infobox_width = | image =Piramidedeltepozteco.jpg | image_size =300px | caption =The Aztec pyramid of El Tepozteco | map_type = | map_size = | map_caption = | location =[[Mexico]] | geo ={{coord|19|0|3.28|N|99|6|4.19|W|}} | latitude = | longitude = | region = | state =[[Morelos]] | district = | municipality =[[Tepoztlan]] | consecration_year = | status = | functional_status =ruined | heritage_designation = | leadership = | website =[http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za01407.html El Tepozteco at INAH] {{es icon}} | architecture =yes | architecture_type =Temple | architecture_style =Aztec | facade_direction =WNW | groundbreaking = | year_completed = | length = | width = | height_max =12.4 meters | materials = }} '''El Tepozteco''' is an archaeological site in the [[Mexican state]] of [[Morelos]]. It consists of a small temple to [[Tepoztecatl]], the [[Aztec]] god of the alcoholic beverage ''[[pulque]]''.<ref name="CA98">Canto Aguilar 1998</ref>
In the middle [[Mesoamerican chronology|Postclassic Period]], various terraces and a small pyramid were built on one of the peaks of the [[Sierra de Tepoztlan]], overlooking the pre-Columbian town of [[Tepoztlan]]. The temple became important enough to attract pilgrims from as far away as [[Guatemala]], although the cult of Tepoztecatl was local to this site.<ref name="CA98"/><ref>Adams 1996, p.360.</ref>
==Description== The temple itself stands at the western side of the site. It consists of a 6.4-meter-high platform supporting a 3.3-meter-high temple base. Upon this stand the remains of the temple building, the remains of which now stand 2.7 meters high.<ref name="CA98"/> The temple was formed of two rooms. The first room opened onto the temple stairs, with two pillars flanking the entrance. In the centre of this room a small hollow was found, containing traces of charcoal and [[copal]].<ref name="CA98"/><ref name="INAH">[http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za01407.html El Tepozteco at INAH] {{es icon}}</ref>
The entry to the small inner sanctum was also flanked by two pillars. The sculpture of Tepoztecatl was probably kept in this room.<ref name="CA98"/><ref name="INAH"/>
The temple was modified several times during its history. The first consisted of a narrowing of the entrance to the inner sanctum by building flanking walls against the formerly free-standing inner pillars.<ref name="CA98"/><ref name="INAH"/> The second, and most important, modification was the addition of stone benches and a small projecting cornice. On the cornice are bas-reliefs of the glyphs of the 20 days of the sacred [[tonalpohualli]] calendar.<ref name="CA98"/>
Dwellings were built on the terraces on the eastern side of the site in order to house the resident priests and their helpers.<ref name="CA98"/>
==Interpretations== [[File:El Tepozteco 2.jpg|thumb|right|Sculpted glyphs on the stone bench inside the temple shrine]] In the ruins of the temple were found two fallen stones with glyphs, one stone bears the name of the eighth Aztec emperor [[Ahuizotl]], the other with the [[Mesoamerican calendars|calendrical date]] "10 rabbit". This date represents the year 1502 A.D., the year that this emperor died. From this, some archeologists have concluded that this was the year in which the temple was built, others suggest that these stones were added later to commemorate the death of the Aztec emperor.<ref name="CA98"/> Some glyphs include a turquoise crown and a shield with arrows, which have led investigators to conclude that the benches were built by the [[Aztec Triple Alliance|Triple Alliance]] some time after 1452 A.D., the year when the Alliance conquered Tepoztlan.<ref name="CA98"/><ref>Matos Moctezuma & Solis Olguín 2002, p.450.</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Mesoamerican pyramids]]
